sec.title: 6th November 2012, 28 Portland Place, W1B 1LY
sec.p: Food Allergies: Meeting the growing challenges

Food allergies are a growing issue in today’s society. The general public are becoming more aware and today’s food safety professionals need to be well trained and knowledgeable about all aspects of food allergy legislation, guidance, symptoms and treatment. Using accelerated learning techniques, this course is unique and memorable. Our practical exercises make learning interesting and fun!
For more information, please contact Claire Robins, crobins@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: 7th November 2012, 28 Portland Place, London, W1B 1LY
sec.p: The Future for Pharmacy and Public Health

This joint conference between the Royal Pharmaceutical Society and the Royal Society for Public Health will offer a platform to update on the ongoing plans for public health and pharmacy. We will hear from those leading the work streams including Mike Farrar on where community pharmacy sits in the new landscape, Helen Gordon on the professional standards for public health pharmacy and Professor John Newton on developing the evidence base for pharmacy’s contribution to public health, as well as the opportunity to hear from those in government.
For information, please contact Claire Robins, crobins@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: 19th November – 20th November 2012, 28 Portland Place, London, W1B 1LY
sec.p: Health and Hygiene in Pools
Chaired by Dr John Lee and Dr Susanne Lee, this promises to provide a crucial update on water safety in pools. A panel of expert speakers will shortly be announced.
For information, please contact Claire Robins, crobins@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: 3rd October 2012, John Snow House, 59 Mansell Street, London E18AN
sec.p: Men’s Health

Men’s health is unnecessarily poor. Too many men still die prematurely with just 66% reaching the age of 75. Men are more likely than women to die from heart disease, cancer and suicide, to be overweight, to smoke and to drink alcohol excessively, yet men are less likely to use a wide range of health services effectively or to take part in health improvement programmes. In response, a special workshop on men’s health has been developed. This one-day course will be of value to all frontline staff working with men who have a remit to encourage males to improve and maintain good health.
For more information please contact Gina, gmohajer@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: 10th October 2012, John Snow House, 59 Mansell Street, London, E1 8AN
sec.p: Health and Wellbeing Boards - An introduction

This half day seminar will examine the new policy changes and will provide a comprehensive brief on the newly proposed operating principles for the Health and Wellbeing Board, their core membership, and key statutory functions. This includes areas such as leading the local joint strategic needs assessment (the JSNA) and the new joint health and wellbeing strategy as well as promoting integrated working and pooled budgets. Drawing on existing and emerging best practice as well as lessons learnt, the seminar will examine the key issues related to the new operating environment.
For more information please contact Gina, gmohajer@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: 25th February - 8th March 2013, 28 Portland Place, London W1B 1LY
sec.p: Diploma in Occupational Medicine - Spring Course

The RSPH is approved by the Faculty of Occupational Medicine (FOM) to run the FOM course to prepare candidates for the Diploma in Occupational Medicine’s written examination and the oral examination based on a portfolio. The FOM Diploma has been designed for registered practitioners. It demonstrates that the holder has achieved a competence appropriate to a generalist working in occupational health. This course is the foundation level qualification required for occupational medicine.
For information, please contact Claire Robins, crobins@rsph.org.uk

sec.title: More women giving birth later in life
sec.p: New figures reveal that more women over 40 years are giving birth. Last year almost 30,000 women over 40 gave birth; three times more than in 1991.

Whilst the birth rate among the over 40s rose by 6.7%, for those aged under 20 years it fell by 8.7%. The figures, which were published by the Office of National Statistics, also showed the number of births in general rose by 22% in the past decade, reaching 724,000 in England and Wales in 2011. Encouragingly, the number of deaths has decreased for the third consecutive year and the figure has stayed below half a million at 484,367.

Fertility declines sharply after 35 years. However it is thought that the reason behind these figures is that more women are choosing to stay on in higher education and establish a career to ensure financial stability before starting a family.

The average age of mothers also increased last year to 29.7, up by 0.1 the previous year. The figures also showed more than a quarter of babies are now born to foreign-born mothers each year and almost half of children are now born to unmarried parents; a rise of more than 7% in a decade.
For more information: www.statistics.gov.uk
